A one-pot chemical synthesis procedure for the production of manganese oxide intercalated graphene oxide (MOI-GO) with elemental manganese content between 11 and 19 wt. % is presented. MOI-GO is then transformed into nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxide (MOI-NrGO) using urea as a nitrogen precursor. MOI-NrGO catalysts exhibit ca. 20 % CO conversion already at 25 °C at high weight hourly space velocities in the range of 41,000–67,000 cm3 h-1 (g MnO2)-1. Catalyst activity increases by up to 2 times up to 100 °C in the case of an optimum elemental manganese content of 18.7 wt. %. Further increase in temperature is accompanied by reduced activity due to the nucleophilic reaction of pyrrolic nitrogen with CO, resulting in carbonate species. Au decoration increases only up to 1.5 times the catalytic activity for the optimum sample. The unexpected high activity of MOI-NrGO at room temperature is mainly attributed to an enhanced electron-transfer characteristic of the NrGO support. Based on X-ray diffraction, nitrogen adsorption/desorption, field emission scanning electron microscopy, Fourier-transform infrared, Raman, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis of the catalyst samples, a reaction mechanism based on the involved surface chemistry is proposed that explains the high activity observed. Graphical abstract CO oxidation mechanism over MOI-NrGO samples. It involves both Langmuir-Hinshelwood and Eley-Rideal type reactions. Reactants approach manganese oxide species intercalated between nitrogen doped reduced graphene oxide sheets, preferably located near the edges. Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO oxidation catalyst Manganese oxide-graphene oxide composite Nitrogen doped graphene oxide Gold nanoparticles Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The pursuit of efficient catalysts for carbon monoxide oxidation has propelled considerable progress in the development of nanocomposite materials, particularly emphasizing graphene oxide (GO) as a catalyst support [1]. GO, a derivative of graphene, is commonly synthesized through the Hummers method which utilizes Mn₂O₇ as the primary oxidant [1,2]. This method oxidizes graphite and introduces oxygen-containing functional groups onto the GO surface, making it a highly suitable substrate for heterogeneous catalysis [1,3]. According to the pioneering work of Dimiev et al. [4], when compared with the Hummers method oxidation protocol, the purification processes play a determinative role in the surface chemistry of the inner and exposed GO layers. Chen et al. further elaborated on the oxidation reaction mechanism of the KMnO4 H2SO4 system of the Hummers method and reached the fundamental conclusion that the final washing step with sufficient HCl is essential for the exclusion of manganese and sulfate ions from GO [5]. As a corollary, the final GO is deprived of any manganese oxide impurity. The present work discloses for the first time the production of manganese oxide intercalated GO by applying the method of Chen et al. [5]. with some modifications, especially excluding the two last steps, i.e. the addition of H2O2 and HCl solutions. As indicated by Chen et al. [5], the use of HCl in the last step is mainly intended for facilitating the substitution of relatively bulky ions like Mn2+and SO4 2- resident between the graphene oxide layers with smaller ions like H + and Cl-, respectively. In this way, insoluble MnO2 produced by the decomposition of Mn2O7 produced in the previous steps remains intercalated between GO layers. The final step is replaced with simple rinsing with water, and as a whole, the synthesis method is made simpler and more environmentally friendly. The amount of intercalated manganese oxides and sulfate depends on the initial amount of KMnO4 added. The latter turns into Mn2O7, which further produces solid MnO2 and dissolved Mn2+ and sulfate ions. The catalytic behavior of the final manganese oxide intercalated GO (MOI-GO) in the CO oxidation reaction in a wide range of reaction temperatures (25–100 °C) has been investigated. In the present work, we also study the effect of nitrogen doping of MOI-GO on the CO oxidation reaction. Nitrogen doping of GO, achieved via ammonia heat treatment, has been demonstrated to improve GO’s surface characteristics significantly [6–8]. This process increases the surface area, introduces structural defects, and reduces the concentration of oxygen-containing groups, leading to enhanced electrical conductivity. Such improvements make nitrogen-doped graphene attractive for applications in catalytic systems. Nitrogen atoms introduce additional active sites on the graphene surface, facilitating CO adsorption and activation at lower temperatures [9]. Nitrogen-doped graphene, with enhanced electronic properties and versatility derived from various nitrogen configurations, presents significant potential as a substrate for metal nanoparticle catalysts in energy applications. The superior electrochemical performance and stability of nitrogen-doped graphene makes it suitable for the methanol oxidation reaction, where improved electron transfer and stability under reaction conditions lead to higher catalytic performance [10]. Further advancements have been made in synthesizing nitrogen-doped graphene through low-temperature pyrolysis using urea as a nitrogen precursor. This method yields high nitrogen doping levels, which improve charge transfer and promote catalysis through non-radical pathways. The increased charge mobility and availability of active nitrogen sites are critical in applications such as CO oxidation, where enhanced electron transfer processes improve catalyst performance [11]. In the present work, we have applied the urea treatment method for producing manganese oxide intercalated in nitrogen-doped rGO (MOI-NrGO) and investigated its CO oxidation behavior in the temperature range of 25–100 °C. Gold-based catalysts, particularly Au nanoparticles (NPs) supported on various substrates, have demonstrated exceptional catalytic activity for low-temperature CO oxidation, though challenges like reversible CO adsorption and gold particle agglomeration affect their long-term stability. The deposition–precipitation method effectively produces highly dispersed gold nanoparticles on reducible metal oxides like ZrO2, optimizing size and dispersion, though issues like carbonate formation persist [12,13]. Furthermore, the choice of support material is critical, with TiO2 and Al2O3 significantly boosting catalytic performance compared to ZnO and ZrO2 . Methods like colloidal deposition, which isolates the support's influence, reveal that support-gold interactions can alter particle shapes and catalytic activity. In the work subject of this study, the effect of Au NPs decoration of MOI-NrGO (Au-MOI-NrGO) on the CO oxidation reaction has also been considered. On the other hand, transition metals atom embedded graphene are emerging as oxidation catalysts. Kropp and Mavrikakis [9] reported an elaborated study on the DFT modeling of the energy barriers of CO oxidation reaction embedding several kinds of transition metal atoms (Mn included) into graphene. They concluded that vacancies on the graphene layer constitute a proper place for the chemical bonding of single transition metal atoms, making the whole active for CO oxidation. In addition, they concluded that doping the pristine graphene with nitrogen enhances the latter reaction rate. Guan et al. [14] have recently reported the effect of embedding manganese into nitrogen-doped graphene on water oxidation. They produced the composite by initially mixing graphene oxide with MnCl2 in an aqueous phase, followed by calcination under NH3 atmosphere. They claimed the formation of MnN4-graphene entities, and not manganese oxides due to the absence of oxygen in the reaction volume, to be responsible for the observed significant reactivity of the resulting catalyst for water oxidation. They supported their results using density functional theory calculations. Throughout this work, we show for the first time that MOI-NrGO results in very active CO oxidation catalysts at low temperatures and high weight hourly space velocities (WHSV). It is shown that catalytic activity may be further enhanced by Au NPs decoration of the latter catalysts, i.e. using Au-MOI-NrGO. Nonetheless, it is argued that the catalytic activity depends on the amount of intercalated MnOx. A highly elaborated picture of the surface chemistry of the final Au-MOI-NrGO composites is provided, and a reaction mechanism explaining the unexpected high CO oxidation performance of the novel material is presented. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and methods The original method of Hummers and Offeman [2], a widely used technique for GO production, was selected as the basis for GO production. However, the method was altered in many aspects. The original method begins with the dissolution of NaNO3 in 98 wt. % sulfuric acid. In our method, NaNO3 addition was omitted. In the first step, graphite (Sigma-Aldrich powder, 99.5 wt. % < 20 µm) was suspended in sulfuric acid (98 wt. %, Dr. Mojallali Chemical Industries Complex, Iran) in an ice bath, with varying amounts of potassium permanganate (Merck) added to achieve nominal weight percentages of 2, 3, and 4 % elemental manganese in the final solid product. The solution was allowed to react in the ice bath, forming manganese heptoxide (Mn2O7), which facilitated the formation of the manganese-graphene composite. The color change from dark green (Mn2O7) to light brown indicated the successful formation of graphene oxide, after which sufficient time was given for complete composite formation. No hydrogen peroxide addition was carried out, as indicated by Chen et al. [5]. The final composite was separated using vacuum filtration to remove excess ions. The final solid product was denominated as MOI-GO. For comparative means, we performed a synthesis procedure corresponding to 3 wt. % manganese in the final product, implementing the HCl (Merck) washing routine of the method implemented by Chen et al. [5], other steps being the same. The final product was denoted as GO. In the subsequent step, nitrogen doping of the manganese oxide-graphene oxide composite was carried out via thermal annealing, a method known for incorporating nitrogen atoms into the graphene lattice. The procedure automatically transforms GO into reduced graphene oxide (rGO). MOI-GO from the previous step (0.5 g) was suspended in a solution produced by dissolving 0.60 g urea (Merck)) in 30 mL of ethanol (Hamoun Teb Markazi Co., Iran). The mixture was treated in an ultrasonic bath for 30 min to form a homogeneous mixture. The latter was then heated on a hot plate at 60 °C to evaporate the solvent while being continuously stirred. The resulting black mixture was finely ground, transferred to a muffle furnace in a crucible, and heated at 350 °C for 30 min in static air, with a controlled heating rate of 5 °C min-1. The obtained furry black powder was washed several times with ethanol and deionized water, followed by drying in an oven at 60 °C overnight. The resulting product was denominated as MOI-NrGO. Based on the nominal Mn element content of the MOI-NrGO sample, the following denomination has been used: 2MOI-NrGO for 2 wt. %, 3MOI-NrGO for 3 wt. % and 4MOI-NrGO for 4 wt. % manganese element. For the decoration of MOI-NrGO product with Au NPs, a colloidal synthesis method was implemented. Poly vinyl alcohol (PVA) (Merck) was employed as a protecting agent, and an aqueous gold solution (100 mg L⁻¹ HAuCl4, Sigma-Aldrich) was prepared. The protecting agent was added at a ratio of Au: PVA = 1.5:1 (mg:mg), and the mixture was vigorously stirred at room temperature for 10 min. Subsequently, an aqueous solution of NaBH4 (0.1N, Merck) was rapidly injected at a molar ratio of Au: NaBH4 = 1:5. This reduction process resulted in the formation of a dark orange-brown solution, indicating the generation of a colloidal gold sol. The MOI-NrGO product was then introduced to the colloidal gold solution under stirring. The system was maintained under stirring until total adsorption of the gold nanoparticles occurred, as evidenced by the discoloration of the solution. The material proportions were selected to obtain a final solid decorated with a total of 1 wt. % Au NPs. To prevent photo degradation, all steps were carried out under the exclusion of light by covering the containers with aluminum foil. The final product was denominated as Au-MOI-NrGO. As a final remark, a denomination of Au-3MOI-NrGO states that the corresponding MOI-NrGO has a nominal 3 wt. % elemental manganese. 2.2 CO oxidation performance assessment The experimental setup utilized in this study involved an integral fixed-bed catalytic reactor. The pressurized feed gas vessel, initially at 50 bars, contained a gas mixture with the following composition: 1600 ppm CO, 1000 ppm C3H8, and 10 vol.% O2, with argon as the balancing gas. After regulating the pressure, the gas flow rate was set to a predetermined range using appropriate valves and flow meters. The gas mixture was then preheated before entering the fixed-bed catalytic reactor, which featured an ½ inch inlet diameter made of stainless steel. Three thermocouples were installed to monitor temperatures at the gas inlet, outlet, and within the catalyst bed. Outlet gas composition was analyzed using a KANE 940 device equipped with CO, NO2, and NO sensors. For the catalytic performance experiments, 200 mg of the synthesized catalyst samples were placed inside the fixed-bed reactor and maintained at the desired temperature for 30 min to reach a steady state. The applied WHSV was in the range of 41 000–67 000 cm3 h-1 (g MnO2)-1. A portion of the reactor’s outlet gas stream was directed into a gas analyzer to measure the concentration of the outlet gas composition [15]. 2.3 Material characterization tests The phase structure of the samples was analyzed using an EQUINOX 3000 (Inel, France) apparatus. The instrument operates at a voltage of approximately 40 kV and a current of 30 mA, utilizing a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å). The measurements were performed over a 2θ range of 10°–80° The surface morphology of catalysts was analyzed by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) using a MIRA 3 LMU (TESCAN, Czech Republic) instrument. The images were captured at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. To prevent filling the submicron surface pores of the catalysts, each sample was coated with an ultrathin layer of platinum. The Au containing sample was not subjected to any coating with conducting elements like Pt. EDX analysis was performed using the same apparatus. Raman spectroscopy analysis was performed using a TakRam N1-541 (Teksan, Iran) apparatus. The Raman spectra were recorded with a 532 nm laser source, operating at adjustable power levels between 10 mW and 100 mW. FTIR analysis was carried out using a Nicolett iSt10 (Thermo Scientific) instrument. The surface chemical composition and electronic states of the Au-MOI-NrGO sample were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), using a Bes Tek (Germany) instrument. The measurement was performed under ultra-high vacuum conditions (10–10 mbar) using a monochromatic Al Kα radiation source with an energy of 1486.6 eV. The elemental Mn content of the catalyst samples were measured using inductive coupled plasma- atomic emission (ICP-AES) analysis method using a Varian 730-ES apparatus. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) analysis of the catalyst samples was performed using a NanoSORD instrument (Sensiran Co., Iran). Reduction was performed contacting the degassed catalyst sample with a 5 mol % H2/95 mol % Ar gas mixture at a flow rate of 10 cm3 min-1 and heating rate of 10 °C min-1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of GO, MOI-GO, MOI-NrGO and Au-MOI-NrGO samples 3.1.1 Phase structure analysis The ultimate catalysts synthesized in this work are the MOI-NrGO and Au-MOI-NrGO series. Based on ICP-AES analysis, the actual Mn element content of the 2MOI-NrGO, 3MOI-NrGO and 4MOI-NrGO samples was 11.4, 18.7 and 17.0 wt. %. For a better understanding of the phase structure and chemistry of the latter catalysts it is necessary to consider the MOI-GO intermediate material produced for the first time by the novel method applied in the present study. The GO material is also considered for a better explanation of the exclusion of the HCl washing step in our unique method. The parent graphite used in this study exhibits a highly ordered and layered structure, reflected in its XRD spectrum through characteristic peaks (Fig. 1 ). The most prominent XRD peak for graphite is observed at approximately 2θ = 26.5°, corresponding to the (002) planes. The corresponding interlayer spacing of the (002) plane is calculated to be 3.35 Å, in agreement with the literature (3.40 Å) [5]. Additional minor peaks, such as those at 2θ = 43.5° and 54.5°, correspond to the (100) and (004) planes, respectively. As seen in Fig. 1, GO exhibits a characteristic peak at approximately 2θ = 11°, corresponding to an interlayer distance of 8.37 Å, significantly larger than that of graphite. This expansion is attributed to oxygen-containing functional groups, such as hydroxyl, carboxyl, and epoxy, which introduce disorder and increase the spacing between graphene layers. Another notable peak, observed in the 40–42° range, is often associated with the (100) plane reflection characteristic of graphene-based materials. The GO XRD pattern has been presented for comparative means, actually, to be compared with the novel material produced in this work, i.e., 3MOI-GO (same figure). The modified version of the Chen method [5] in this work results in MOI-GO materials. Fig. 1 incorporates the X-ray pattern of the 3MOI-GO sample. Compared to the GO sample, the persistence of graphene oxide peaks centered around 11° and 42°, although slightly shifted, is evident. However, extra peaks are observed that could be attributed to different phases of manganese oxide entities: MnO2 (36.6 and 42.0 °), δ-MnO2 (25.46°), Mn2O3 (23.0 and 33.0°) and Mn3O4 (18°). Summarizing, the novel method produces a graphene oxide structure with residual manganese oxides, which may reside between the graphene oxide layers and/or on the surface of the stack of the graphene oxide layers. The interlayer spacing of the (002) plane of the graphene oxide phase of 3MOI-GO has been calculated to be 8.58 Å, significantly larger than 8.37 Å of GO, where the manganese oxide phases were absent in the X-ray diffraction pattern. This outcome is explained based on the chemistry behind the synthesis procedure applied in the present work: The synthesis procedure consists of only two steps: a) Chemical reaction between KMnO4, H2SO4, graphene, and water; b) Washing the final composite with water. In the first step (a), the following reactions take place: (1) K M n O 4 + 3 H 2 S O 4 → K + + M n O 3 + + H 3 O + + 3 H S O 4 − (2) M n O 3 + + M n O 4 − → M n 2 O 7 (3) 3 M n 2 O 7 → 6 M n O 2 + 3 O 2 + O 3 The ozone and oxygen molecules produced in the last reaction are the main reactants attacking the graphene stacks and opening them, allowing the entrance of M n O 4 − and M n O 3 + ions that have a nominal diameter of around 4.5 Å, much larger than the pristine graphene interlayer spacing of 3.35 Å. Accordingly, manganese oxide entities like M n O 2 get intercalated within the graphenic layers. The intercalation process is also accompanied by graphene oxidation by the oxygenic oxidants, which creates new carbon-oxygen bonds like epoxides. The described processes eventually result in an interlayer spacing of 8.58 Å. The denomination of the solid products at this stage is thus justified: MOI-GO stands for manganese oxide intercalated-graphene oxide. Fig. 2 illustrates the X-ray diffraction patterns of the MOI-NrGO kind of materials synthesized in this study. As described in the experimental section, the latter materials were produced by mixing MOI-GO products with urea and heating at 350 °C in the air atmosphere. Under such a treatment, graphene oxide materials are generally transformed into reduced graphene oxide, and the urea precursor ultimately leads to nitrogen doping of the latter. As indicated in Fig. 2, the prominent peaks associated with reduced graphene oxide (rGO) have been indicated. The interlayer spacing of the rGO sheets has been calculated as 3.370, 3.443, and 3.444 Å for the 2MOI-NrGO, 3MOI-NrGO, and 4MOI-NrGO, respectively. The concept of rGO for the MOI-NrGO samples is thus justified. The interlayer spacing has approached that of the pristine graphene (3.35 Å) after the doping process. In addition, the spacing increases with the amount of initial KMnO4 added in the synthesis procedure. The same figure includes a typical X-ray diffraction spectrum of a gold nano-particle decorated MOI-NrGO sample (Au-3MOI-NrGO). The XRD pattern reveals distinct peaks corresponding to a crystalline cubic phase structure of metallic gold. Characteristic peaks appear at 2θ values of approximately 38.2°, 64.6°, and 77.8°, which are attributed to the (111), (220), and (311) planes of gold’s face-centered cubic (FCC) structure, respectively. As indicated in the same figure, the rGO peaks are still dominant. 3.1.2 Nitrogen adsorption/desorption and FE-SEM analysis Table 1 summarizes the specific surface area and specific pore volume of the pristine graphite, 3MOI-NrGO, and Au-3MOI-NrGO samples. The specific surface area of the pristine graphite increases from 21.9 to 69.3 m2 g-1 for the 3MOI-NrGO sample. Decoration with Au NPs further increases the specific surface area of the latter to 85.6 m2 g-1. The latter treatment is accompanied by a significant specific pore volume increase of around 60 %. The substantial increase in the specific surface area and pore volume is mainly attributed to the action of the residual HCl in the Au colloidal solution during the Au-decoration treatment of the MOI-NrGO samples. Upon application, the acid may dissolve part of the intercalated manganese oxide material, increasing specific surface area and pore volume. Fig. 3 shows the corresponding nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms of the GO, 3MOI-NrGO, and Au-3MOI-NrGO samples. Fig. 4 illustrates the FESEM picture (secondary electron image) of the parent graphite, GO, 3MOI-GO, and 3MOI-NrGO samples. The layered structure of the initial graphite material persists in the GO and 3MOI-GO samples. The GO to rGO thermal treatment procedure induces irregularities in the morphology of the carbonaceous layer stacks. Fig. 5 illustrates an FESEM picture (backscattered electron image) of the Au-3MOI-NrGO sample. It is observed that the Au NPs are well-dispersed on the exposed surface, with a rather sharp particle size. Considering many samples, the average particle size of Au NPs was determined to be approximately 25 nm. 3.1.3 FTIR and XPS analysis A complementary vision of the chemical structure of the novel materials may be obtained by assessing their FTIR spectra. Fig. 6 depicts the FTIR spectra of the 3MOI-GO, 3MOI-NrGO, and Au-3MOI-NrGO samples. The 3MOI-GO sample produced by the novel method resembles a graphene oxide material sample due to the following characteristic peaks [16–18]: 1734.14 cm-1 (C=O stretching vibrations), 1140.69 cm-1 (C-O-C symmetric stretching vibrations), 882. 27 cm-1 (C-O-C asymmetric stretching vibrations). The peak at 1619.91 cm-1 is not characteristic and belongs to O-H vibrations. Instead, the peak centered at 579.99 cm-1 features the presence of the manganese oxide species inherent of the novel synthesis method employed. Upon nitrogen doping and production of a reduced-graphene oxide material, a clear change in the carbon-related characteristic peaks occurs. The peak centered at 1562.02 cm-1 is attributed to the presence of sp2 groups, resulting from the reduction of graphene oxide. The peaks centered at 1111.28 and 1061.14 cm-1 are attributed to the bending and stretching vibrations of COH groups, respectively. The peak centered around 601.88 cm-1 is attributed to Mn-O vibrations of intercalated Mn3O4 entities between the reduced-graphene oxide sheets produced [19]. The peaks centered at 478.39 and 407.39 cm-1 are attributed to the intercalated MnOx species between the reduced-graphene oxide sheets produced [20]. Finally, the presence of nitrogen in the form of C-N groups is supported by the shoulders in the range of 1430–1480 cm-1 [21]. The effect of decoration of 3MOI-NrGO with Au NPs results in the FTIR spectrum indicated as Au-3MOI-NrGO in Fig. 6. Although a relatively small peak at 1720.67 cm-1 indicates the permanence of C=O groups, the peak centered at 1610.27 cm-1 is dominant and suggests a high content of sp2 groups in the sample. The appearance of a small peak at 1224.09 cm-1 is attributed to the CO-C group symmetric stretching vibration. The peak at 701.96 cm-1 is ascribed to Au NPs. The remaining peaks centered at 579.88 and 528.88 cm-1 are attributed to the MnOx species. The persistence of the shoulder in the range of 1430–1480 cm-1 confirms the presence of CN groups. For obtaining a deeper general outlook of the final composite surface chemistry, the XPS spectra of the Au-3MOI-NrGO sample are illustrated in Fig. 7 . Considering first the C 1s spectrum, deconvolution results show 82.8 % sp2 (284.3 eV), 11.32 % carbonyl (287.60 eV ), and 5.77 % epoxide (286.43 eV) groups [22]. The prevailing sp2 character of the carbon sheets confirms the FTIR analysis presented before, and it justifies the term rGO for the carbonaceous component of the composite. Accordingly, the carbon sheets are expected to have a relatively high electrical conductivity. Referring to the N 1 s spectra in Fig. 7, it is observed that nitrogen exists in three different states regarding the NC bonding, i.e. 39.24 % as pyrrole-like N atom (399.10 eV) [6], 37.97 % as pyridine-like N atom (398.10 eV) [6], and 22.78 % as quaternary N atom (401.30 eV) [23]. Accordingly, the electrical conductivity of the carbonaceous sheets is further improved due to the doping imparted. The Au element 4f state XPS spectrum is challenging. Au exists both as metallic (87.61 %) and slightly oxidized (12.39 %) states. The corresponding binding energies for the metallic state are 84.1 and 87.8 eV, and those for the oxidized state are 85.3 and 88.8 eV, respectively [24,25]. The final spectrum considered is that of O 1s. The predominant peak belongs to the adsorbed state of O2, i.e. the O-, O2 2-, and O2 - molecules. Its binding is centered at 531 eV [25], and constitutes 75.31 % of the total O 1s area. Lattice O2 constitutes 10.78 % of the whole and is located at 529.4 eV [26]. Part of the O 1s spectrum shows the existence of oxygen as carbonate entities (13.91 %), centered at 532.5 eV [27]. These findings will be used in the explanation of the catalytic behavior of the Au-MOI-NrGO and MOI-NrGO materials produced in this study. It is imperative to report that the total XPS spectrum of the Au-3MOI-NrGO sample (not shown) does not show any sulfur atom. This is remarkable, as the EDX analysis generally showed the existence of sulfur in the Au-MOI-NrGO and MOI-NrGO samples. Our method results in intercalated MnO2 entities within the rGO sheets. It is reminded that the latter are prone to react to some extent with the incoming H2SO4 molecules entering the sheets during the oxidation of the carbon elements of the sheets by the released oxygen (di-oxygen and ozone) produced in reaction (3): (4) M n O 2 + H 2 S O 4 → 0.5 O 2 + H 2 O + M n S O 4 Although sulfate ions may be present (as shown by energy dispersive X-ray analysis, not shown), the absence of sulfur in the XPS survey spectrum (not shown) shows that sulfate entities should exist as intercalated between the graphene sheets. In other words, the exposed surface of the graphene sheets is deprived of MnSO4 through the simple rinsing with water procedure implied in this study. 3.1.4 Raman spectroscopy analysis A final inspection of the chemical structure of the parent graphite, GO, 3MOI-NrGO, and Au-3MOI-NrGO samples is carried out considering their Raman spectra (Fig. 8 a and b). The parent graphite exhibits a characteristic G band peak centered at 1578.07 cm-1, representing the sp2 bonded carbons [6]. The D band is located at 1362.11 cm⁻¹ (indicative of structural defects) and has a relatively weak intensity. Upon oxidation of graphite to GO, the G band broadens and shifts to 1614.25 cm-1 due to the formation of new functional groups, especially C-O and C=O groups. The D band shifts to 1372.81 cm-1 and significantly increases in intensity, showing the creation of substantial defects in the parent graphene sheets. The 3MOI-NrGO spectrum shows a G band at 1588.44 cm-1 and an intense D band at 1367.48 cm-1. The Au-3MOI-NrGO spectrum also has a G band at 1598.77 cm-1 and an intense D band at 1378.16 cm-1. The ID/IG intensity ratio serves as an indicator of sheet defect density. For graphite, this ratio is low (0.157), signifying fewer defects. For GO, this ratio rises significantly (0.887) due to the introduction of oxygen-containing functional groups. Upon manganese oxide intercalation and application of the reduction process (3MOI-NrGO sample), the ID/IG intensity ratio increases to (1.06), reflecting considerable additional defects due to MnOx intercalation and nitrogen incorporation within the carbonaceous sheets. Decoration with Au NPs (Au-3MOI-NrGO sample) does not induce any significant change in the latter ratio, i.e. no further structural defects are produced. The main outcome of the Raman spectra involves the patterns observed in the 0–1000 cm-1 shift range (Fig. 8b). The 3MOI-NrGO sample exhibits four clear peaks at 329.59, 525.74, 573.93, and 645.62 cm-1. The peak centered at 329.59 cm-1 is attributed to skeletal vibrations of manganese oxides [28], especially Mn3O4 [29]. The peaks at 525.74, 573.93, and 645.62 cm-1 are attributed to stretching modes of Mn-O bonds in MnO6 octahedral layers [28]. Such peaks have been reported for β-MnO2 30 . Peaks due to the deformation mode of Mn-O bonds are present at Raman shifts between 505 and 513 cm-1, but need deconvolution for better analysis [28]. Accordingly, Fig. 8b confirms the preservation of manganese oxide entities within the reduced graphene stacking of sheets. It goes without saying that some MnOx species are also present on the exposed reduced graphene oxide sheets, as previously deduced by the XPS analysis. Upon Au NPs decoration, the peaks undergo shift and intensity increase. Intensity enhancement is attributed to the surface plasmonic effects of Au NPs [31]. The peaks centered at 310.93 cm-1 are attributed to Mn3O4 entities. The double peaks of 483.28 and 495.42 cm-1 are attributed to α-Mn2O3 30. The peak at 501.50 cm-1 is attributed to the deformation mode of Mn-O bonds of MnO2 [32]. The peaks at 537.82 and 543.83 cm-1 are assigned to β-MnO2 [29]. Finally, the peak centered at 651.57 cm-1 is attributed to α-Mn2O3 [30]. The results of Raman analysis are in good agreement with XPS analysis in the case of Au-3MOI-NrGO, as the manganese oxidation numbers of 2+, 3+, and 4+ are observed in both. In addition, the same oxidation states have been observed for the non-decorated 3MOI-NrGO samples. 3.1.5 H2-TPR analysis Fig. 9 shows the H2-TPR analysis of the 2MOI-NrGO, 3MOI-NrGO, 4MOI-NrGO and Au-3MOI-NrGO samples. The MOI-NrGO series samples (not containing Au) exhibit broad peaks with a maximum appearing at temperatures higher than 600 °C. Bulk and graphene-supported MnOx, where x assumes values in the range of 1-2, are known to reduce at temperatures smaller than 500 °C [33–35]. The shift of the reduction temperature towards much higher values such as 679 °C for the 3MOI-NrGO sample shows that the reduction process is mass transfer limited. In other words, intercalated MnOx entities reduce at higher temperatures with respect to supported MnOx counterparts, as hydrogen should penetrate through the graphene sheets. In the case of the Au-3MOI-NrGO sample, the peak appearing at 650 °C is attributed to Au clusters. Au supported on carbonaceous materials has been reported to reduce at temperatures higher than 600 °C [36]. The consumption of hydrogen has been measured to be 16 035, 15 079, 7 890 and 9 902 (µmole H2 (g catalyst)-1). There is no direct relationship between the amount of hydrogen consumption and the Mn content of the samples. This is attributed to different oxidation numbers (and even mixed oxidation numbers) of the MnOx entities intercalated between the graphene sheets. Nonetheless, the short-period of treatment employed for the decoration of MOI-NrGO samples with Au NPs might decrease the MnOx content of the samples due to contact with highly acidic media. 3.2 Catalytic performance The catalytic performance of the MOI-NrGO series and Au-3MOI-NrGO catalysts for the CO oxidation reaction is illustrated in Fig. 10 . Considering first the MOI-NrGO series of materials, it is observed that they are all very active for the oxidation reaction. They are already active at room temperature (25 °C), and this activity is nearly constant up to 45 °C. From 45 up to 70 °C, the activity of the MOI-NrGO materials increases more than two-fold. Increasing the temperature from 70 °C results in a decrease in the CO oxidation activity. By referring to Fig. 10, it is observed that the 3MOI-NrGO material exhibits the highest activity throughout the temperature range under study. At this stage, it is imperative to remind that such a catalytic performance for a nitrogen-doped rGO material with a relatively very small loading of manganese oxide-type materials (11 – 19 Mn wt. %) is surprising. As indicated in the caption of Fig. 10, the WHSV values implemented are relatively high (41 000- 67 000 cm3 h-1 (g MnO2)-1), i.e. the space time used is low. To give a clear idea, it is informative to allude to the catalytic performance of a series of relevant materials. MnO₂, whether as a catalyst or as a catalyst support, has not been regarded as effective for low-temperature applications [37]. Wang et al. [38] reported that manganese oxide in each of the MnO2, Mn3O4, and Mn2O3 oxide states becomes active for the CO oxidation reaction only at a temperature of 102, 152, and 77 °C, respectively. Recently, Tian et al. [39] reported a T50 (temperature for a CO conversion of 50 %) of 134 and 151 °C for α-MnO2 and α-Mn2O3 at a WHSV of 60 000 cm3 h-1 (g MnOx)-1. The same authors reported a T50 of 83 °C for a novel highly disordered manganese oxide catalyst at the same WHSV. In the case of our 3MOI-NrGO sample, a T50 of 40 °C has been reached at a higher WHSV of 67 000 cm3 h-1 (g MnO2)-1. Accordingly, it may be stated that the novel MOI-NrGO series of catalysts possess an unexpectedly high activity with respect to known manganese oxide catalysts. It goes without saying that in the MOI-NrGO series, manganese oxide constitutes a small weight percentage of the whole material. The main component of the latter catalysts is NrGO. It seems trivial that there exists a strong interaction between the NrGO component and the manganese oxide species that leads to such a high CO conversion activity of the whole. To gain a better understanding of the possible role of the NrGO support, it is noteworthy to mention that rGO is known to act as a promoter for CO conversion reaction when used with cobalt oxide as the main support [27]. The main role of rGO has been described as acting as an efficient conducting material, enhancing electron transfer. It is reminded that we used nitrogen-doped rGO as the main support for our catalysts. It is well known that the substitution of carbon atoms in rGO with foreign atoms like nitrogen results in the opening of band gap, eventually enhancing rGO’s conductivity. The addition of Au NPs in the case of the 3MOI-NrGO sample leads to an increase in the CO conversion activity (same Fig. 10). Decoration of manganese oxide phases with Au NP’s has been reported to increase CO conversion [38], and its effect follows the sequence Au/Mn2O3 > Au/MnO2 > Au/Mn3O4. Considering the open literature, we expected a much higher magnitude of activity enhancement. A possible explanation for this abnormal behavior may be related to the relatively very low content of manganese oxides in the composite catalyst. Before trying to elaborate a reaction mechanism for the novel catalyst presented, it is noteworthy to consider a peculiar phenomenon observed in Fig. 10. All the catalysts under consideration (with or without Au NPs decoration) undergo a fall in activity after 70 °C. This is explained as follows. Although doping with nitrogen enhances electron mobility on the rGO sheets and eventually increases CO conversion activity, it also poses a limitation to the maximum conversion attainable. The reason for the latter claim resides in the high nucleophilic character of the nitrogen hetero-atom in the rGO sheets. Considering pyrrolic nitrogen as a typical example (see Fig. 11 ), after CO to CO2 oxidation on the catalyst surface takes place, the formed CO2 may get attached to the nitrogen atoms and undergo a chemical reaction leading to a carbonate species. Although our XPS analysis showed the presence of carbonate species, it is emphasized that carbonate formation is a speculation and in-situ characterization methods (like in-situ XPS or on-line GC–MS) are needed for giving a robust statement. The accumulation of such carbonate species impedes further CO adsorption and eventually leads to a lower overall catalytic activity. This phenomenon is particularly prevalent in gold-based catalysts, where the interaction of CO or its oxidation by-products, such as CO₂, results in the formation of surface carbonates [12]. It is emphasized that the catalytic performance of the catalysts under investigation did not undergo any detectable change after several repetitions of the experiments or long time on stream. Accordingly, it may be stated that the MOI-NrGO series of catalysts (with and without Au) did not deactivate under the reaction conditions imposed. At this stage, based on the discussions presented in the characterization section and the explanation of the catalytic results, an overall picture of the low-temperature reaction system may be presented in terms of the mechanism described below. In the first step, oxygen vacancies are produced, and oxygen gas is released into the surrounding atmosphere: (5) M n 4 + − O − M n 4 + ⇌ M n 3 + − V O ̈ − M n 3 + + 0.5 O 2 Considering a Langmuir-Hinshelwood type mechanism, oxygen gas in the feed may be adsorbed near the produced vacancies: (6) M n 3 + − V O ̈ − M n 3 + + O 2 ⇌ M n 3 + − V O ̈ O 2 − M n 3 + The effect of a nitrogen-doped rGO on the reaction mechanism is highlighted by the following reactions (7) and (8). NrGO is a highly conductive 2D material and may provide electrons to the adsorbed oxygen species. Reactions (7) and (8) result in O2 - or O2 2- species, and this is in accordance with the previously discussed XPS analysis results. (7) M n 3 + − V O ̈ O 2 − M n 3 + + N r G O − ⇌ M n 3 + − V O ̈ O 2 − − M n 3 + + N r G O (8) M n 3 + − V O ̈ O 2 − M n 3 + + N r G O = ⇌ M n 3 + − V O ̈ O 2 = − M n 3 + + N r G O A Langmuir-Hinshelwood type reaction for the adsorption of CO on the manganese oxide active site is envisaged. The presence of negatively charged adsorbed oxygen species enhances the CO molecules' adsorption process by providing a more positive manganese adsorption center (Mn3+δ instead of Mn3+): (9) M n 3 + δ − V O ̈ O 2 − − M n 3 + + C O ⇌ M n 3 + C O − V O ̈ O 2 − − M n 3 + (10) M n 3 + δ − V O ̈ O 2 = − M n 3 + + C O ⇌ M n 3 + C O − V O ̈ O 2 = − M n 3 + In the case of Au NP’s decoration, CO adsorption is enhanced by the following reactions: (11) A u + C O ⇌ A u − C O a d s (12) M n 3 + δ − V O ̈ O 2 − − M n 3 + + A u − C O a d s ⇌ M n 3 + C O − V O ̈ O 2 − − M n 3 + + A u (13) M n 3 + δ − V O ̈ O 2 = − M n 3 + + A u − C O a d s ⇌ M n 3 + C O − V O ̈ O 2 = − M n 3 + + A u The following steps highlight again the effect of a highly conductive NrGO: (14) M n 3 + C O − V O ̈ O 2 − − M n 3 + + N r G O → M n 3 + C O − V O ̈ O 2 − M n 3 + + N r G O − (15) M n 3 + C O − V O ̈ O 2 = − M n 3 + + N r G O → M n 3 + C O − V O ̈ O 2 − M n 3 + + N r G O = CO2 evolution from the surface occurs through several steps. Here, we apply a simplified overall reaction: (16) M n 3 + C O − V O ̈ O 2 − M n 3 + → M n 3 + − V O ̈ O − M n 3 + + C O 2 An Eley-Rideal type mechanism is adopted for the production of CO2 without an adsorption step for CO: (17) M n 3 + − V O ̈ O − M n 3 + + C O → M n 3 + − V O ̈ − M n 3 + + C O 2 The exceptional high activity of the MOI-NrGO and Au-MOI-NrGO series of composite catalysts is thus explained by referring to the reaction mechanism involving reactions (5) to (17), based on the surface chemistry elucidated in the materials characterization section. The schematic of the proposed mechanism for the MOI-NrGO catalyst particles is shown in Fig. 12 . In the case of Au NP’s decoration, a schematic may be found in Fig. S1. As a final remark, attention should be paid to what are considered active sites for the MOI-NrGO materials. As the latter exist as stacking of rGO sheets with a repeating distance of 3.77 to 3.44 Å as calculated based on X-ray diffraction analysis, diffusion of reacting species (CO and O2) and effusion of product species (CO2) between the sheets is highly constrained. It is presumed that manganese oxide clusters residing on the exposed outer rGO sheets and those lying on the edges are the main ones responsible for the catalytic behavior observed. Accordingly, it would be difficult to calculate a turn over frequency (TOF) for the novel material, and the authors of the present work limit themselves to report the “general” activity instead of the TOF. The MOI near the edges lies between NrGO sheets, which act as excellent electron conductors. As the MnOx species are actually intercalated between the graphene sheets, they are simultaneously provided with electrons from the upper and lower sheets. It is presumed that this phenomenon promotes the total reaction. The Au-3MOI-NrGO catalyst exhibited the best CO oxidation performance. The elemental composition of the Au-3MOI-NrGO sample based on EDX analysis turned out to be 31.56, 40.28, 19.18, 11.20 and 2.48 wt. % C, O, Mn, N and Au, respectively. Fig. 13 shows the EDX diagram of the latter sample: Our manganese-intercalated reduced graphene oxide (MOI-NrGO) catalysts show outstanding performance in CO oxidation compared to existing systems (Table 2 ). For example, the 3MOI-NrGO catalyst achieves over 80 % CO conversion at just 60 °C - significantly better than the reported Pt/TiO₂ which requires 213 °C for only 50 % conversion [40], and comparable to advanced Au/Mn₃O₄ catalysts that reach full conversion at 98 °C [41]. The gold-modified version, Au-3MOI-NrGO, completes CO oxidation below 80 °C, matching the performance of top-performing Pt/C1 and Au/rGO/Co₃O₄ catalysts [27]. Remarkably, even without noble metals, our 3MOI-NrGO outperforms transition metal alternatives like Cr-CoX [42] (which needs 145 °C for 8 0 % conversion). This excellent activity stems from the unique structure where manganese oxides are embedded between graphene layers, combining the catalytic properties of MnOx with graphene's excellent conductivity and large surface area. The intercalated structure also prevents nanoparticle aggregation, solving a common durability problem in conventional catalysts. 4 Conclusions The method presented in this study for the transformation of graphite to graphene oxide is essentially different from the most common preparative methods like Staudenmaier, Hofmann, Hummers, and Tour (Recent advances in nitrogen-doped graphene oxide nanomaterials: Synthesis and applications in energy storage, sensor electrochemical applications, and water treatment). All these methods aim at producing metal oxide free graphene oxide. Our method, intentionally preserves manganese oxide within the graphene oxide sheets and also on the exposed surface of the stacked sheets. As a corollary, there is no need to add manganese oxide, and in a relatively large quantity, afterwards to the carbonaceous support (or vice versa), as a common practice. It has been shown that nitrogen doping produces an appropriate rGO material that enhances the CO conversion reaction by acting as a source and sink of electrons throughout the reaction mechanism. Although the latter phenomenon is highly desired, experimental results showed that nitrogen centers may also promote chemical instability of the catalyst through carbonate species production due to their highly nucleophilic character. Accordingly, there exists a tradeoff between the conductive and nucleophilic character of nitrogen-doped rGO. The novel catalyst composite showed high CO oxidation activity in a WHSV range of 41 000–67 000 cm3 h-1 (g MnO2)-1, which is actually relatively high and provides very low ‘residence time’ for the reacting species in the feed gas to interact with the catalytic surface. The best results for the MOI-NrGO catalysts have been obtained with a 18.7 wt. % Mn content. Au decoration does improve the catalytic activity, but only by a small factor of around 1.5. This is because the un-decorated catalyst already possesses a significant CO oxidation activity. coredata.dc:description: A one-pot chemical synthesis procedure for the production of manganese oxide intercalated graphene oxide (MOI-GO) with elemental manganese content between 11 and 19 wt. % is presented. MOI-GO is then transformed into nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxide (MOI-NrGO) using urea as a nitrogen precursor. MOI-NrGO catalysts exhibit ca. 20 % CO conversion already at 25 °C at high weight hourly space velocities in the range of 41,000–67,000 cm3 h-1 (g MnO2)-1. Catalyst activity increases by up to 2 times up to 100 °C in the case of an optimum elemental manganese content of 18.7 wt. %. Further increase in temperature is accompanied by reduced activity due to the nucleophilic reaction of pyrrolic nitrogen with CO, resulting in carbonate species. Au decoration increases only up to 1.5 times the catalytic activity for the optimum sample. The unexpected high activity of MOI-NrGO at room temperature is mainly attributed to an enhanced electron-transfer characteristic of the NrGO support. Based on X-ray diffraction, nitrogen adsorption/desorption, field emission scanning electron microscopy, Fourier-transform infrared, Raman, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis of the catalyst samples, a reaction mechanism based on the involved surface chemistry is proposed that explains the high activity observed.
